author: Eugene Boisvert
title: Kensington Rd lookout: Great city views — or a haven for sex, boozy parties? |
text:
A ONCE-popular eastern suburbs lookout will have its city-views restored, despite concerns the site could become a haven for sexual activity and drunken parties.
Burnside Council voted at a meeting last night to remove 11 trees blocking city-views from the Kensington Rd lookout.
The top carpark at the Wattle Park lookout — known locally Skye lookout — was closed to vehicles in 2002 and the area made a dry zone after nearby residents complained about drinking, hooning and lewd behaviour at the site.
Since then, trees have grown to block views of the city.
Councillor Lance Bagster has spearheaded a campaign to have the lookout reopened. Source: News Corp Australia
Cr Lance Bagster, who organised two petitions calling for the lookout to be restored to its former glory, denied any such move would lead to bad behaviour.
“None of the options will make the lookout a haven for hoons or bad behaviour, mass orgies or boozy parties,” Cr Bagster said.
If anything, Cr Bagster said the area had become worse since it was closed to cars and looked like a “war zone”.
However, fellow Burnside Ward councillor Graham Bills said the area had vastly improved since it was closed to traffic.
Cr Bills was the officer-in-charge of Norwood Police Station before he retired in 1999.
He said patrols would respond to “five or six” incidents per night at the lookout before it was closed and declared a dry zone.
He said reopening it could attract people with “immoral purposes and illegal activity”.
“We don’t need to act on this at the moment,” Cr Bills said.
“It can go on the backburner — it has been there already for 14 years.”
The Kensington Rd lookout in Wattle Park. Source: Supplied
Another councillor, Grant Piggott, said he had seen a mattress at the lookout, but this was refuted by Cr Bagster.
Rather than going ahead with the major upgrade, councillors voted for the axing of the trees.
This will cost $14,088, plus $6300 extra in maintenance in the first year.
The top carpark will not be reopened to traffic.
Public consultation on a further revamp will go ahead once decisions have been made on renaming the lookout as the 100 Years of Anzac Lookout , erecting a memorial at the site and the Development Assessment Commission deciding whether or not to approve plans by quarry company Boral to open a road connecting Kensington Rd near the lookout with McBeath Drive in Skye .
